Impacts of nanomaterials on bacterial quorum sensing: differential effects on different signals†
Anee Mohanty,‡ab Chuan Hao Tan‡b and Bin Cao*ab
Using Pseudomonas syringae and Pantoea stewartii as model
organisms, we quantified the influence of silver nanoparticles and
single-wall carbon nanotubes on the production of different acyl-
ated homoserine lactones for quorum sensing (QS). This study re-
ports for the first time on differential effects exhibited by nano-
materials on different QS signals.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Recent studies have suggested that bacteria manifest complex social lifestyles.1,2 Cell-to-cell communication among individual members in a bacterial population or community is the key to their social behaviours and communal functions.3 The most common approach to supply information and synchronize social activity in bacteria is the production of certain chemicals as signalling molecules. Quorum sensing (QS) is one of the most important chemical-based signalling systems that bacteria commonly use to coordinate cooperative behaviours.4,5 QS allows individual bacteria to assess local cell density and to engage in cooperation once a threshold density has been reached.6
The acylated homoserine lactones (AHLs)7 are QS signals used by most Gram-negative bacteria. The AHL-type QS systems have been identified in a large number of Gramnegative bacterial species belonging to the α, β, and γ subclasses of proteobacteria8 and have been shown to be highly conserved across different species. These include pathogens such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Yersinia enterolitica and Serratia liquefaciens, plant symbionts such as Rhizobium spp., and environmental bacteria such as Nitrosomonas spp. and
Geobacter uraniumreducens.9 In these bacteria, the AHL-type QS systems have been shown to regulate a wide variety of bacterial physiological processes including bioluminescence,10 biofilm formation,11 host pathogenesis,12,13 plasmid transfer, motility, secondary metabolite production,14 and sporulation.15 AHL-type QS has also been demonstrated to play a critical role in engineering processes such as membrane biofouling16 and granulation in biological wastewater treatment.17,18
The ubiquitous presence of the AHL-type QS systems in environmental bacteria and their capability in regulating a broad range of bacterial functions suggests a pivotal role of the AHL-type QS in defining and shaping complex community structures and functions for ecological services. Environmental factors such as nutrient availability,19 temperature, pH20 and environmental stresses21 may contribute to different quorum sensing responses. For example, it has been shown that a short-term starvation may enhance quorum sensing signal production in Myxococcus xanthus.22 Contaminants in the environment may also interact with

Nano impact
The extensive use of nanomaterial-containing products has led to increasing concern over the impacts of nanomaterials on the environment. Antimicrobial effects of nanomaterials against environmental bacteria have been widely reported, while the sublethal impact on bacterial cell-to-cell communication in a community, in particular, quorum sensing (QS) remains elusive. QS is used by many bacteria to coordinate cooperative behaviours and has been shown to play a critical role in various natural and engineered bioprocesses. A number of different QS signals are often produced concurrently and each may be involved in regulating different bacterial activities. We report for the first time that different QS organisms may respond differently to nanomaterials and result in differential QS signalling profiles. This may cause a complex influence on the overall structure and function of the whole community. Our finding significantly advances current knowledge toward a comprehensive understanding of the sublethal effects of nanomaterials on QS signalling in bacterial communities.

environmental bacteria and interfere with their AHL-type QS systems, altering various bacteria driven processes, e.g., biogeochemical cycles, nutrient uptake by plants, wastewater treatment, and pathogenesis. One group of contaminants that are of emerging concern are nanomaterials, i.e., materials with a size ≤100 nm in at least one dimension.23,24 Owing to their unique physicochemical properties, nanomaterials have been increasingly used over the past decade across various industries.25 This leads to the possibility of nanomaterial release into the environment at different stages of the nanomaterial-containing product life cycle. The impacts of nanomaterials on environmental bacteria including bactericidal and sub-lethal effects have been extensively studied in recent years.26,27 However, to date, very limited studies exploring the impacts of nanomaterials on bacterial QS signalling have been reported and conclusions in most studies have been drawn based on nanomaterial-induced changes in certain QS-regulated functions28,29 rather than direct quantification of QS signals. Since each bacterial species usually produces a number of different QS signals, our knowledge on how these QS signals respond differently to nanomaterials is lacking but is required for a comprehensive understanding of the effects of nanomaterials on bacterial QS systems.
The objective of this study was to investigate the influences of nanomaterials on different AHL-type QS signals. Gram-negative bacteria Pseudomonas syringae and Pantoea stewartii were used as model organisms and both have been reported to produce AHL-type QS signals.30–32 The nanomaterials used in this study were silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) and single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs). The influences of AgNPs and SWCNTs on the production of several key AHLs in P. syringae and P. stewartii were quantitatively assessed. This study reports for the first time on the effects of nanomaterials on the production of individual QS signals.

sections.heading: Bacterial strains and nanomaterials
sections.text:
Stock cultures of P. syringae pv. tomato DC3000 (DC3000)33 and P. stewartii (NCBI accession no. KC252900)31 were maintained in lysogeny broth (LB) medium with 25% glycerol at −80 °C. Cultures were grown aerobically at 30 °C in LB medium. The SWCNTs were synthesized using the arc-discharge method (AP-SWNT, tube diameter of ∼1.4 nm, Carbon Solutions, Inc.) and purified through a centrifugation-based method as previously described.34 AgNPs with sodium citrate as stabilizer with a size of 20 nm (TEM-based) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Singapore).
Inhibitory effects of nanomaterials on bacterial growth
P. stewartii and P. syringae were grown in LB in the presence of SWCNTs (0–500 mg L−1) or AgNPs (0–2 mg L−1) at different concentrations. Concentrations of SWCNTs and AgNPs in the range of 0–500 mg L−1 and 0–2 mg L−1, respectively, were used for determining the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC), i.e., the lowest concentration that inhibits visible
growth of a bacterial culture. The optical density at 600 nm (OD600) was used to monitor bacterial growth. Since nanomaterials may interfere with OD600 readings, cell growth was further quantified using a colony forming unit (CFU) method.35–37
Inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS)
Cells were grown in the presence and absence of AgNPs at 0.5 mg L−1 for 24 h. The culture supernatant was harvested by centrifugation at 6000g for 15 min. The cell free supernatant was filtered through a 0.2 μm syringe filter. The silver ion (Ag+) concentration was quantified using an ICP-MS instrument (ELAN DRC-e, Perkin Elmer; Waltham, MA) as previously described.34,38
Extraction of AHLs from bacterial cultures
P. stewartii and P. syringae were grown in LB in the presence and absence of 20 mg L−1 SWCNTs or 0.5 mg L−1 AgNPs at 30 °C in a shaking incubator (200 rpm). Samples taken at 0 h and 24 h were used to quantify cell growth following the CFU method described above.35 Extraction of AHLs from each bacterial culture at the early stationary phase (24 h) was conducted as previously described.39 Briefly, 100 ml of dichloromethane was mixed with 50 ml of the culture supernatant. The dichloromethane extract was dried in a nitrogen gas stream and then resuspended in methanol/water (1 : 1 v/ v) for further analysis by LC-MS/MS (Shimadzu, Singapore).

sections.heading: Quantification of AHL signals
sections.text:
The parameters for LC-MS/MS were set according to a previously reported procedure for AHL analysis with slight modifications.18 The XR-ODS C18 column and a flow rate of 0.3 ml min−1 were used for all samples. The mobile phase consisted of a linear gradient (40–95%) of solvent B (methanol with 0.1% formic acid) and solvent A (25 mM ammonium formate with 0.1% formic acid). Following LC separation, samples were then ionized by electrospray ionization under positive mode and detected using the multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) approach.51,52 Each standard MRM profile, including specific LC retention time, appearance of precursor ion m/z and two transition ions, as well as relative intensity of the two transition ions, was used as a reference. A full scan, ranging from m/z 100 to 350 was used to identify the putative AHLs, coupled with precursor ion scan mode was conducted in comparison with the standards. The following synthetic AHLs (>97%) purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Singapore) were used as AHL standards: N-butyryl-DL-homoserine lactone (C4-HSL), N-hexanoyl-DLhomoserine lactone (C6-HSL), N-(3-oxohexanoyl)-DL-homoserine lactone (3OC6-HSL), N-heptanoyl-DL-homoserine lactone (C7-HSL), N-octanoyl-DL-homoserine lactone (C8-HSL), N-(3-oxooctanoyl)-L-homoserine lactone (3OC8-HSL), N-decanoyl-DL-homoserine lactone (C10-HSL), N-(3-oxodecanoyl)-L-homoserine lactone (3OC10-HSL), N-dodecanoyl-

The standard curves were constructed with a concentration ranging from 0.5 to 200 mg L−1 for absolute quantification of signals in real samples. Every AHL had two transition ions which were used to identify the AHL and the transition ion with the highest intensity was employed to construct the standard curves. Post run analysis such as analyte peak areas integration was done using LabSolutions (Shimadzu). The limits of detection and quantification for each AHL were calculated with a signal-to-noise ratio of 3.3 and 10, respectively. Triplicate blank injections were performed between sample injections to avoid sample carry over.

sections.heading: Statistical analysis
sections.text: All statistical analyses were conducted using Prism 6 Version 6.04 (GraphPad, U.S.A.) or PRIMER 6 Version 6.1.15 & PERMANOVA+ Version 1.0.5 (PRIMER-E, United Kingdom). Multivariate analysis commonly used in ecological studies were adopted to determine the overall changes of AHL profiles between different treatments. The AHL profiles were clustered based on Euclidean distance with logarithm (X + 1) transformation and visualized using MDS plots.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
Determination of sub-inhibitory concentrations for AgNPs and SWCNTs
The AgNPs and SWCNTs inhibited growth of P. syringae and P. stewartii in a concentration dependent manner (Fig. S1†), which is consistent with previous studies on the bactericidal activities of nanomaterials.40,41 The MIC of AgNPs and SWCNTs under our experimental conditions was ∼1 mg L−1 and ∼200 mg L−1, respectively. No growth inhibition was observed for AgNPs and SWCNTs at a concentration of 0.5 mg L−1 and 20 mg L−1, respectively, against both organisms after 24 h of cell growth (Table 1). Hence, the sub-inhibitory
concentrations of 0.5 mg L−1 and 20 mg L−1 were used for AgNPs and SWCNTs, respectively, to examine their effects on QS signalling in P. syringae and P. stewartii.
Identification of key AHLs produced by P. syringae and P. stewartii
The AHLs produced by the two bacteria were identified using LC-MS/MS based on standard curves and the mass spectra of 13 synthetic AHLs as quantitative references (Fig. 1A). Different AHL profiles were obtained for these two organisms. P. syringae mostly produced 6 short chain AHLs, namely C4HSL, C6-HSL, 3OC6-HSL, C7-HSL, C8-HSL, and 3OC8-HSL. Among these, C6-HSL and 3OC6-HSL (∼2.23 mM each) were the most abundant QS signals (accounting for ∼98% of total signals, Fig. 1B). Whereas P. stewartii produced 11 different types of AHLs including both short chain and long chain AHLs: C4-HSL, C6-HSL, 3OC6-HSL, C7-HSL, C8-HSL, 3OC8HSL, 3OC10-HSL, C12-HSL, 3OC12-HSL, C14-HSL, and 3OC14-HSL (Fig. 1C). The most abundant AHL signal in P. stewartii was 3OC6-HSL (accounting for ∼81% of total signals).
Influence of AgNPs and SWCNTs on the production of different AHLs

In particular, the presence of AgNPs in P. syringae cultures resulted in >50% reduction of C4-HSL, ∼24% reduction of C6-HSL, and ∼31% reduction of 3OC6-HSL. The concentration of Ag+ in the culture media containing 0.5 mg L−1 AgNPs after 24 h of incubation was determined using ICP-MS to be 12.5 ± 0.4 μg L−1. We then examined the impact of AgNO3 at a concentration of ∼12.5 μg L−1 on the model organisms and no inhibitory effect on QS signalling could be observed. However, the quantified concentration of Ag+ might not be a true representation of that released from AgNPs because a portion of Ag+ would have been neutralized by the media components. Hence, AgNO3 at a concentration of 0.5 mg L
−1 (same as that of AgNPs) was used as another control. The effects of AgNPs and Ag+ on QS were examined using a bioassay (see ESI† for method details) prior to further quantification of individual AHLs. Since no inhibitory effect of Ag+ on QS signalling could be observed (Fig. S1 in ESI†), only cultures exposed to AgNPs were further analysed using LC-MS/MS (Fig. 2 and 3). Taken together, our results suggest that the effects reported here can be attributed to the nanoparticulate nature of AgNPs. In contrast, in the presence of 20 mg L−1 SWCNTs, the level of most AHLs remained unchanged except for C4HSL and C8-HSL, which exhibited a reduction of ∼13% and ∼21%, respectively. Intriguingly, the production of most
AHLs in P. stewartii was not significantly affected by either 0.5 mg L−1 AgNPs or 20 mg L−1 SWCNTs. The only exception was C4-HSL, for which was observed a ∼21% reduction in the presence of AgNPs (Fig. 3).
A nonmetric multidimensional scaling (nMDS) analysis of the AHLs produced by both P. syringae and P. stewartii as impacted by AgNPs and SWCNTs is shown in Fig. 4. In P. syringae, samples from the AgNP-treated cultures formed a distinct cluster.
These results suggested a significant shift in the AHL profiles, in particular, C4-HSL, when P. syringae was grown in the presence of AgNPs. The samples from SWCNT-treated cultures closely resembled the control without SWCNTs and were clustered together, indicating no overall changes in the AHL profiles. In contrast, all the samples from P. stewartii cultures with and without AgNPs or SWCNTs were largely scattered and no discrete clusters could be found, suggesting no overall changes in the AHL profiles produced by P. stewartii. The differential effects of different ENMs on AHLs production in different species might be attributed to a combination of ENMs physicochemical properties and bacterial response mechanisms to environmental stresses. The physiochemical properties such as sizes, shapes and compositions of the two ENMs used in this study differ significantly, which might lead to different biological effects. Previous reports have suggested different modes of action for different nanomaterials. For example, AgNPs can either attach onto the bacterial cells and alter their membrane permeability and damage the cellular respiration chain or penetrate into the cells and interact with biomolecules such as proteins42 and nucleic acids,43 while SWCNTs mostly act through

direct physical contact or exert oxidative stress which compromises the cell membrane integrity.40 Moreover, the aggregation behaviour of the two ENMs in the presence of the organic matter in the culture media might be different, which may in turn affect their interactions with bacterial cells. Furthermore, the effect of AgNPs is also different for different bacterial strains. This host specificity could be attributed to interspecific differences in bacterial characteristics. For example, the two bacterial strains used in this study vary in terms of their extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) composition44,45 and thus might interact differently with the tested ENMs.
Taken together, our results show that the effects of nanomaterials on bacterial QS signalling are highly dependent on the bacterial species, and more importantly, the production of different QS signals may respond differently to contaminant exposure. The production of AHLs is a complex biological process and the exact mechanism of how nanomaterials interfere with different AHL synthesis pathways needs further investigation.
In previous studies, the effects of nanomaterials on bacterial QS signalling have been reported mostly based on the assay of QS-regulated activities such as violacein production in Chromobacter violaceum.28,29 However, a number of different QS signals are often produced concurrently and each may be
involved in regulating different bacterial activities. For example, violacein production has been shown to be induced by short chain AHLs (C4–C8) and inhibited by AHLs with N-acyl side chains from C10 to C14.46 Our results reveal that the production of different AHL-type QS signals may respond differently to nanomaterials at sub-inhibitory concentrations. Both P. syringae and P. stewartii are soil bacteria that are usually associated with plant roots47,48 and the AHLs produced by these organisms have been shown to regulate various interactions between bacteria and their plant hosts.49 Understanding the differential effects of nanomaterials on the production of different AHLs would allow us to better assess their impacts on specific bacteria–host interactions. In addition, QS represents both intra- and inter-species signalling and QS-enabled cooperation is beneficial to the local population or community as a whole.50 Hence, differential effects exhibited by nanomaterials on different QS signals in certain QS signal producers may result in a complex impact on the overall function of the whole community.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: Taken together, our results reveal that the effects of nanomaterials on bacterial QS signalling are highly dependent on bacterial species, and more importantly, the production of different QS signals in one species may respond differently. This study significantly advances our current knowledge toward a comprehensive understanding of the sublethal effects of nanomaterials on bacterial QS signalling.
